item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
This is the AI development we've all feared.Sony researchers have created an AI bassist that can follow your music.
https://www.musicradar.com/news/sony-ai-bassist

item.title: Kristin Branson
item.description:
Bumblebees socially learn behaviour too complex to innovate alone
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07126-4#MOESM3
"Culture refers to behaviours that are socially learned and persist within a population over time. Increasing evidence suggests that animal culture can, like human culture, be cumulative: characterized by sequential innovations that build on previous ones... This suggests that social learning might permit the acquisition of behaviours too complex to â€˜re-innovateâ€™ through individual learning."

item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description: @computingnature Thanks for pointing out this interesting lecture! There clearly is no "representational drift" in prefrontal cortex, when behavior is stable. It would have been nice to see activity of those same neurons 2 months later when the task goes back to the original one. For others who might be interested, here is the link with a timestamp at the beginning of the talk: https://www.youtube.com/live/Kq5f36OwFKU?si=4KQ6iBNgcWDydwqQ&t=4098

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
Various oscillatory waveform shapes result in distinct spike correlations.Oscillatory Waveform Shape and Temporal Spike Correlations Differ across Bat Frontal and Auditory Cortex
https://www.jneurosci.org/content/44/10/e1236232023
#neuroscience

item.title: Ulrike Hahn
item.description: @NicoleCRust @emma_cogdev the thing I still donâ€˜t get is that data faking seems to me to cut out the only bit about science that is truly fun/rewarding: finding out something about the world..ethics applications? writing? dragging papers through the publication process? all annoying activities worth it only for finding out something new and interestingâ€¦.why bother?

item.title: Ulrike Hahn
item.description: @mrcompletely @NicoleCRust @emma_cogdev I donâ€˜t really want to dissuade you from thinking well of me, but my bafflement at Stapel isnâ€˜t moral, itâ€˜s instrumental: occasions of external positive feedback seem far and few between in academia, so if you donâ€˜t intrinsically enjoy what you are doing itâ€˜s not a great place to be, but there seems little to nothing left to intrinsically enjoy if you are just making things up.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Volunteer outsiders doing a far better job than French authorities and institutions...https://www.science.org/content/article/failure-every-level-how-science-sleuths-exposed-massive-ethics-violations-famed-french

item.title: d a t green
item.description: A close look at the Donelan libel settlementHow did a minister make her department feel exposed to expensive legal liability?New by me, at Substackhttps://emptycity.substack.com/p/a-close-look-at-the-donelan-libel

item.title: Manlio De Domenico
item.description:
A new #CompexityThoughts short essay is out. This time about the (un)known mechanisms of dreaming: https://open.substack.com/pub/manlius/p/inception-or-reality?r=n4iyo&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=trueUnraveling complexity: building knowledge, one paper at a time!
Not yet subscribed? It's never too late, and it's 100% free.#Neuroscience #Brain #Mind #ComplexSystems

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Neanderthals and Denisovans: Homo sapiens or not? Depends on which scientist you ask! I take a look at the most personal version of the species question in my latest email newsletter. https://buttondown.email/carlzimmer/archive/fridays-elk-march-8-2024/

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
Come to the GRC on Frontal Cortex. There will be an amazing lineup of speakers. And me.
#neuroscience

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
Brain and mind researchers of all types: I hope you'll join this conversation at Cognitive Computational Neuroscience (August 6-9, Boston).There, I'll be zooming out to 40,000 feet to inspire discussion around the question: Why have we been learning so much about the brain and mind for so many decades, but our ability to treat its dysfunction has been so frustrated? The answer to that question informs what I affectionately call the Grand Plan â€” a description, in broad strokes, of how brain and mind researchers of all types plan to move from where we are now to societal benefits (including treating brain dysfunction). I'm envisioning a community-centered conversation unlike any I've seen before; because it's unusual, I unpack it here:
https://www.nicolerust.com/grandplanI'm grateful to the CCN organizers for providing an opportunity for this. I hope you'll join in!https://2024.ccneuro.org/

item.title: Carsen Stringer (she/her)
item.description: @MatteoCarandini yes, that would have been very interesting to see! I heard your lab had a very interesting poster about (the lack of) representational drift. Our guess is that some of what people describe as representational drift could actually be unsupervised learning (https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.02.25.581990v1).

item.title: Yohan John ðŸ¤–ðŸ§
item.description: Fast synaptic learning is pretty amazing: it seems to require only very sparse firing (both in terms of percentage of cells firing and in terms of firing rate), but it can lead to very long-term changes.Piette et al 2020. Engrams of Fast Learning. https://doi.org/10.3389/fncel.2020.575915 #Neuroscience

item.title: Tim Verstynen
item.description: Example #3412 of why the US healthcare system is toxic and harmful:The last time I got COVID it chewed up 11% of my small vessel lung capacity, giving me permanent asthma. My doctor agreed that I absolutely need to take Paxlovid whenever I get COVID to avoid further lung damage.So, this week I got COVID. When my partner went to our pharmacy to pick it up, we were told that our insurance would only cover $300 of the $1600 charge. So basically CVS Caremark (and Pfizer) is extorting me $1300 on a literal life saving medication because they can.Meanwhile, their CEO alone got compensated $21.3M last year. Corporate greed is literally killing people.

item.title: Frederick
item.description: When you download an academic paper in PDF form (from say, arXiV), how do you decide on the file name? What matters to you? Full paper titles? "et al" author names? Publication date? I'm never sure how to name these files...#Academia #Research #Science #OpenScience #arXiv #Preprints #AcademicResearch
